what: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
title: Keep track of dates and medications through pregnancy and fertility treatment
text: work--progress R package tracking dates medications pregnancy fertility treatment. early stages development. Update 2023-03-25: long hiatus, now actively returning work project. R code getting major overhaul. package best-practices, like documentation, tests, vignettes, pkgdown website etc, also forthcoming. ’ll hex sticker !

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
text: Calculate due date

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
text: start_date Start date start_type Start type cycle Cycle length

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
text: due date

title: Calculate due date — calculate_due_date
code: my_start_date <- as.Date("2023-01-31") calculate_due_date(my_start_date) #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, November 07, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 17, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 21, 2023 (42 weeks) due_date <- calculate_due_date(my_start_date, "conception") #> ℹ Estimated due date: Tuesday, October 24, 2023 #> ℹ Estimated birth period begins: October 03, 2023 (37 weeks) #> ℹ Estimated birth period ends: November 07, 2023 (42 weeks) due_date #> [1] "2023-10-24" class(due_date) #> [1] "Date"

what: Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
title: Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: Functions get set default due date used throughout package. affects calculations various functions determine pregnancy progress timing. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_due_date() sets "pregnancy.due_date" option get_due_date() retrieves .

title: Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: due_date Date object specifying estimated due date, NULL unset current value

title: Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
text: functions invisibly return current due date setting: get_due_date() returns current setting (Date object) NULL set set_due_date() returns due date value set

title: Get or set the pregnancy.due_date option — due_date-option
code: # Store original setting original_due_date <- getOption("pregnancy.due_date")  # Check current setting get_due_date() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.due_date` set as an option. #> ℹ You can set it by...  # Set due date using as.Date set_due_date(as.Date("2024-09-15")) #> ✔ Due date set as September 15, 2024 #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `due_date` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `due_date` argument. #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.due_date = 2024-09-15) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. get_due_date() #> Your due date is set as September 15, 2024.  # Set due date using lubridate library(lubridate) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘lubridate’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     date, intersect, setdiff, union set_due_date(ymd("2024-09-15")) #> ✔ Due date set as September 15, 2024 #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `due_date` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `due_date` argument. #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.due_date = 2024-09-15) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`. get_due_date() #> Your due date is set as September 15, 2024.  # Restore original setting set_due_date(original_due_date) #> ✔ Due date set as NULL #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `due_date` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `due_date` argument. #> ℹ To make this `due_date` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.due_date = ) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `due_date` option with `get_due_date()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.due_date')`.

what: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Calculates displays far along pregnancy specific date, including weeks pregnant, days remaining due date, overall progress percentage.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: how_far(on_date = Sys.Date(), due_date = NULL, person = NULL)

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: on_date Date object. date calculate pregnancy progress. Defaults current system date. due_date Date object. expected due date. NULL, try use "pregnancy.due_date" option. Required option set. person person pregnant, determine grammar output message. NULL, try use "pregnancy.person" option. Defaults "" neither argument option set. Use 1 "" addressed first person, use2or""` addressed second person, string give third-person name.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: Invisibly returns number days along pregnancy. Prints formatted message console pregnancy progress information.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: function assumes standard pregnancy length 280 days (40 weeks) calculating progress. handles past, present, future dates appropriately adjusting message grammar. calculation shows 42 weeks pregnancy, different message displayed noting unusual duration. function uses cli package formatted message output supports proper pluralization weeks/days messages.

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
text: pregnancy.due_date: Date object setting default due date pregnancy.person: Character string setting default person

title: Calculate pregnancy progress and time remaining — how_far
code: # Current progress with explicit due date # Note that output will depend on date the function is run # This is run on 2025-01-27 how_far(due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01")) #> ℹ You are 18 weeks and 0 days pregnant. #> ℹ That's 22 weeks and 0 days until the due date (July 01, 2025). #> ℹ You are 45% through the pregnancy.  # Progress on a specific date how_far(on_date = as.Date("2025-06-01"),         due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01")) #> ℹ On June 01, 2025, you will be 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant. #> ℹ NA #> ℹ NA  # With custom person how_far(on_date = as.Date("2025-06-01"),         due_date = as.Date("2025-07-01"),         person = "Sarah") #> ℹ On June 01, 2025, Sarah will be 35 weeks and 5 days pregnant. #> ℹ NA #> ℹ NA  # Set global options if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ set_due_date(as.Date("2025-07-01")) how_far() } # }

title: An example medications table — medications
text: data frame example medications might used fertility treatment/first trimester. example data frame might used meds argument meds_remaining().

title: An example medications table — medications
An example medications table — medications
text: data frame 14 rows 5 columns: medication Name medication format Format medication quantity Number taken per day start_date Date start taking medication stop_date Final date medication taken. See details.

title: An example medications table — medications
text: Note medication (prednisolone example) several rows, first quantity taken per day changes, needs taken non-consecutive days.

title: An example medications table — medications
code: medications #> # A tibble: 14 × 5 #>    medication   format    quantity start_date stop_date  #>    <chr>        <chr>        <dbl> <date>     <date>     #>  1 progynova    pills            3 2023-04-21 2023-04-30 #>  2 LDA          pills            1 2023-04-21 2023-05-07 #>  3 prednisolone pills            2 2023-04-26 2023-05-07 #>  4 progynova    pills            6 2023-05-01 2023-07-11 #>  5 cyclogest    pessary          2 2023-05-03 2023-07-11 #>  6 lubion       injection        1 2023-05-03 2023-07-11 #>  7 clexane      injection        1 2023-05-08 2023-09-05 #>  8 prednisolone pills            4 2023-05-08 2023-07-11 #>  9 prednisolone pills            3 2023-07-12 2023-07-14 #> 10 prednisolone pills            2 2023-07-15 2023-07-17 #> 11 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-18 2023-07-20 #> 12 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-22 2023-07-22 #> 13 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-24 2023-07-24 #> 14 prednisolone pills            1 2023-07-26 2023-07-26

title: Title — meds_remaining
text: Title

title: Title — meds_remaining
code: meds_remaining(   on_date = Sys.Date(),   meds = NULL,   group = c("medication", "format") )

title: Title — meds_remaining
text: on_date date meds meds group group

title: Title — meds_remaining
text: prints console, returns data frame invisibly

title: Title — meds_remaining
code: meds_remaining(on_date = as.Date("2023-04-30"), meds = medications) #> # A tibble: 6 × 2 #>   medication   quantity_remaining #>   <chr>                     <int> #> 1 LDA                           8 #> 2 clexane                     121 #> 3 cyclogest                   140 #> 4 lubion                       70 #> 5 prednisolone                297 #> 6 progynova                   435

what: Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
title: Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: Functions get set default person used messages throughout package. affects grammar pronouns used various function outputs. Settings persist current R session , unless added .Rprofile. set_person() sets "pregnancy.person" option get_person() retrieves .

title: Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: person character string number specifying person. Can : "", "1", "1st", "first", numeric 1 first person "", "2", "2nd", "second", numeric 2 second person name third person NULL unset current value

title: Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
text: functions invisibly return current person setting: get_person() returns current setting (character string) NULL set set_person() returns person value set

title: Get or set the pregnancy.person option for pregnancy-related messages — person
code: # Store original setting original_person <- getOption("pregnancy.person")  # Check current setting get_person() #> ! You do not have `pregnancy.person` set as an option. #> ℹ You can set it by...  # Set to first person (using string) set_person("I") #> ✔ person set as 'I' #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `person` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `person` argument. #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.person = I) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> The person option is set as 'I'.  # Set to second person (using number) set_person(2) #> ✔ person set as 'You' #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `person` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `person` argument. #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.person = You) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> The person option is set as 'You'.  # Set to a specific name set_person("Sarah") #> ✔ person set as 'Sarah' #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `person` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `person` argument. #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.person = Sarah) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`. get_person() #> The person option is set as 'Sarah'.  # Restore original setting set_person(original_person) #> ✔ person set as '' #> ℹ For this R session only, functions in the pregnancy package will now use this #>   `person` option. #> ℹ So for now, you do not now need to supply a value to the `person` argument. #> ℹ To make this `person` option available in all R sessions, include this code #>   in your ".Rprofile": #>   options(pregnancy.person = ) #> ℹ You can edit your ".Rprofile" by calling `usethis::edit_r_profile()` #> ℹ You can retrieve the `person` option with `get_person()`, #>   or with `getOption('pregnancy.person')`.
